sense.name: an official written record
sense.examples: This old book appears to be an 16th-century register of births and deaths in an English village. The innkeeper asked us to sign the guest register. She's in all the social registers of town.

sense.name: pitch range of a voice, either human or instrumental
sense.examples: The boy's voice dropped a register during puberty. The opera singer could maintain a smooth unbroken tone between her registers. He enjoyed the dusky lower register of the basset horn.

sense.name: a computer data cache
sense.examples: These values are stored in a register and used by a later computation. The CPU of my computer has several registers.

sense.name: adjustable panel to regulate airflow in a space, e.g.,room or furnace
sense.examples: The register in the room was set to 72 degrees Fahrenheit. She moved the register to increase the air-conditioning in the room. The register for the furnace is on the wall in the living room.

sense.name: passageway in floor or wall to allow airflow
sense.examples: She stood over the register in the hallway to get warm. Air from a register in the floor was causing the curtain above it to flutter slightly.

sense.name: cash box with adding machine attached
sense.examples: The clerk said she'd ring me up at the other register. Two masked men entered the liquor store and demanded all the money from the register. Modern registers automatically compute the change of the customer.

sense.name: a social dialect of a natural language
sense.commentary: REGISTER[+system][+communication][+language][+natural][+dialect][+social] Note: implies distinct usage of vocabulary and pronunciation
sense.examples: In their society, men and women use different registers in ceremonial speech. In his new book, the linguist has described various registers in ethnic urban communities of the northeast.

sense.name: slide on a musical organ that controls pipes
sense.examples: The organist moved the register as he played the piece. Which pipes does this register control?
